title: Keep wheels build up-to-date
body:
Actual testing is by manually launching and ssh into the cluster to see if the installed sky get updated.

A simplified testing procedure:

1. Under the directory containing `setup.py`, run `pip wheel --no-deps . --wheel-dir /tmp`. This generates the wheel `/tmp/sky-*.whl`
2. Use `unzip` command to see the content of the wheel.
3. Delete `build` in the current directory, the wheel and unzipped files in `/tmp`
4. Update your code, repeat 1-2 to see if the content in the wheel includes updated code.

Closes #296
Closes #260

title: file_mount -> Storage shorthand for YAMLs and docs
body:
This PR adds a shorthand for users to directly use file_mounts to create and mount sky.Storage objects. This makes the YAML less wordy for most users. For power users, the declarative `storage` and `storage_mount` specification is still supported.

```yaml
file_mounts:
  # This uses rsync to directly copy files from your machine to the remote VM.
  /datasets: ~/datasets

  # This uses sky Storage to first create a S3 bucket named sky-dataset,
  # copies the contents of ~/datasets to the remote bucket and makes the
  # bucket persistent (i.e., the bucket is not deleted after the completion of
  # this sky task, and future invocations of this bucket will be much faster).
  # The bucket is mounted at /datasets-storage.
  /datasets-storage:
    name: sky-dataset
    source: ~/datasets
    force_stores: [s3] # Could be [s3, gcs], [gcs] default: None
    persistent: True  # Defaults to True, can be set to false.

  # This re-uses a predefined bucket (sky-dataset, defined above) and mounts it
  # directly at /datasets-s3.
  /datasets-s3: s3://sky-dataset
```

A demo is included in `examples/storage_demo.yaml`

title: Terminate stopped instance for aws
body:
> After looking into the code of ray, it seems like the problem comes from this [line](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/7f1bacc7dc9caf6d0ec042e39499bbf1d9a7d065/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/commands.py#L424), where the `provider.non_terminated_nodes()` only returns nodes that are `running` or `pending` ignoring those in `stopped` or `stopping` status.

Using the aws cli and the region information from our cluster config, we can now terminate the stopped aws instance.

title: Fix the hanging problem with `sky start`
body: This PR solves the problem in #205, by reducing the retry times for boto3 for AWS (retry times: 12 -> 5). 12 is the default number defined in ray, and 5 is the default number defined by awscli. Previously, it hangs for a very long time (about 40min) when insufficient capacity occurs during `sky start`. The reason for that is the time for retry increases exponentially. [reference](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/276ff2b7eda27b2e16c9f16da887a9e861112459/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/constants.py#L68)

title: Fix the default image on Azure for K80/A100
body:
Our current default image used in Azure fails on K80 (our gpunode) and A100 due to the below reasons.
K80: `HyperVGenerations` mismatched
A100: cuda driver mismatched

This PR addresses this issue with correct image (Azure HPC) and generation version.

See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/nda100-v4-series
> Due to increased GPU memory I/O footprint, the ND A100 v4 requires the use of [Generation 2 VMs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/generation-2) and marketplace images. The [Azure HPC images](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/hpc/configure) are strongly recommended. Azure HPC Ubuntu 18.04, 20.04 and Azure HPC CentOS 7.9 images are supported.

Also `HyperVGenerations` in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/nc-series

title: Public Bucket Checking + Error Handling
body:
Solves Zhanghao's Git Issue #295 

This PR does:
- [x] Can connect to public buckets
- [x] Better error handling if a bucket name is taken
- [x] Checks if bucket can be uploaded to; if not, handle error

## Tests

```
def test_public_bucket_aws():
    # Public Dataset: https://registry.opendata.aws/tcga/#usageexamples
    storage_1 = storage.Storage(name="tcga-2-open", source="s3://tcga-2-open")
    storage_2 = storage.Storage(name="tcga-2-open",
                                source="/Users/michaelluo/Downloads/temp/")
    try:
        # This should fail as you can't write to a public bucket
        storage_2.get_or_copy_to_s3()
    except Exception:
        pass
    storage_2.delete()
```

```
def test_public_bucket_gcp():
    # Public Dataset: https://registry.opendata.aws/tcga/#usageexamples
    storage_1 = storage.Storage(name='cloud-tpu-test-datasets',
                                source='gs://cloud-tpu-test-datasets')

    storage_2 = storage.Storage(name='cloud-tpu-test-datasets',
                                source='/Users/michaelluo/Downloads/temp/')
    try:
        # This should fail as you can't write to a public bucket
        storage_2.get_or_copy_to_gcs()
    except Exception:
        pass
    storage_2.delete()

```

title: Create daemon in new session; fix logging problem
body:
This PR is an attempt to fix the problem mentioned in #287, by creating the daemon for cleaning up child processes in a new session, instead of using `shell=True`, so that the daemon may not be killed when the session is killed by the OS.

Another change in this PR is to fix the unaligned logging caused by replacing the CRLF with LF (e.g. `sky exec debug -- 'for i in $(seq 1 120); do echo $i; sleep 1; done'` provided by @concretevitamin ). We now only replace the CRLF with LF when the output is logged to driver by ray.

title: Fix laggy terminal after Ctrl+C from `sky exec` while streaming logs
body:
The problem is described in #246. The terminal will be very laggy after Ctrl+C during the `sky exec` is streaming the logs (`subprocess.run('sky logs cluster job_id')`). 

After some experiments, it seems that the problem does not exist when I ran `sky logs` directly in the terminal. Also, when the terminal becomes laggy, I will not able to do connect to the server with `sky queue`. Thus, I suspect that the `subprocess.run()` not correctly kill the ssh making the ssh still connected in the current session, so that makes the terminal laggy.

Main changes: Change the `subprocess.run('sky logs')` to directly run the statements in the `sky logs`.

-- Update --

By checking the `ps aux`, the process for the `sky logs` (`ssh -T ...`) still runs in the background, even after we kill the `sky exec` with ctrl+c. `subprocess.run` (and the `backend_utils.run`) is problematic for running commands that lasts a long time, as the process will still exist after ctrl+c. `shell=False` does not help for this.

TODO:
- [x] Find out the reason why the fix works

Tested:
- [x] The test in #276 (cancelling pytorch dataparallel program)
- [x] ctrl+c while the tailing the logs in `sky exec`

title: Fix yaml check & use workdir for `sky exec` fast path
body:
Tested: 
```
» cat test.sh
#!/bin/bash
for i in $(seq 1 120); do
  echo $i
  sleep 1
done

» sky exec debug --workdir=. ./test.sh
```

Previously, this command got interpreted as a yaml, because `yaml.safe_load("./test.sh")` passes and returns a str.

Fixes #187; tested with
```
» sky launch -c debug 'non\ exist.yml'
Entrypoint 'non\\ exist.yml' looks like a yaml path but does not exist (is there a typo?).
It will be treated as a command to be run remotely. Continue? [y/N]:

» sky launch -c debug nonexist.yaml         
Entrypoint 'nonexist.yaml' looks like a yaml path but does not exist (is there a typo?).
It will be treated as a command to be run remotely. Continue? [y/N]:

» sky launch -c debug prototype/examples/minimal.yaml
Task from YAML spec: prototype/examples/minimal.yaml
...
```

title: Support multi-node tasks with any num_nodes smaller than the cluster
body:
This PR adds `$SKY_NODE_IPS` and `$SKY_NODE_ID` to the os environment before running multi-node commands, and also changes the python API for distributed training to support a dynamic number of nodes for training. #255 

Advantages:
1. We can now get the IP in runtime so that we can launch tasks with k nodes (using the IPs of the allocated nodes) on an n-node cluster (k<n). 
2. We can now run the distributed training with the yaml file.

Main changes:
1. export those two environment variables, $SKY_NODE_ID and $SKY_NODE_IPS, before running the multi-node commands.
2. Change the task.run dictionary design from `{ip: run_for_ip}` to `{node_id: run_for_node_id}`.
3. Replace `run(ip_list: List[str]) -> Dict[str, str]` function with `run(node_i: int, ip_list: List[str]) -> str`, so that the each node can generate the corresponding run command from the `run` function.

Tested / TODO:
- [x] `examples/env_check.yaml`
- [x] `examples/resnet_distributed_torch_app.py`
- [x] `examples/resnet_distributed_torch.yaml`
- [x] Update `examples/resnet_distributed_tf.py`
- [x] Run `examples/resnet_distributed_tf.py`/`examples/resnet_distributed_torch.py` (2 nodes) on a cluster with 4 nodes.

Update:
A way to run node-specific task, in yaml:
```yaml
run: |
  if (( SKY_NODE_ID == 0 )); then
    python main.py
  fi
  if (( SKY_NODE_ID > 4 )); then
    python test.py
  fi
```

In python API:
```python
def run_fn(node_rank: int, ip_list: List[str]) -> Optional[str]:
  # processing
  return f'python train.py --node {node_i} --master_addr {ip_list[0]}'
```

Future TODO:
1. Multi-node ray tune is not available in our code for both the original and current design, due to the placement group constraint.

title: Fix interactive node resource check when no cloud is specified
body:
This should get merged after #216.

`resources.is_same_resources` will currently return `False` if a user re-uses a cluster where the default cloud is `None` and the launched resources are something like `AWS(p3.2xlarge)`, causing our resource check to fail for cases like the following:

```
sky gpunode -c t1 --gpus V100
sky gpunode -c t2 --gpus K80
```

To handle this, the cloud is inferred from the launched resources before running the resource check with user-specified resources.

title: Hide pip warning messages
body:
Older pip versions would generate various warning messages, and we want to hide them from users. One is known as https://stackoverflow.com/questions/67301493/what-does-this-deprecation-warning-mean-and-how-to-fix-it.

**Why not disable them with pip flags?**: Unfortunately, these flags generate warnings and errors when using new pip versions, because newer pip versions could drop these flags. Besides, pip could generate `WARNING: You are using pip version xxx; however, version yyy is available.` at any time. Another workaround could be using the `redirect_process_output` util, but I am not confident with pip warnings.

Close #218

title: Fix the source ~/.bashrc not working problem
body:
This PR fixes the following problem:
1. `sky gpunode` and do `echo export TEST_VAR="test" >> ~/.bashrc`.
2. `sky exec -c sky-gpunode-username --gpus K80:1 -- "source ~/.bashrc && echo TEST_VAR \$TEST_VAR".`
Our original code will not print out the `$TEST_VAR`, since `source ~/.bashrc` does not work when the `-i` option is not given. This will cause problems when users add things in `~/.bashrc` during setup, and want to use them during `run`, e.g. adding `WANDB_API_KEY` to the `~/.bashrc`.

title: Fix defunct job after cancelling
body:
We are currently using `subprocess` to run the command line. The child process may be defunct when the python program is killed. Fixed by creating a subprocess to kill the defuncted child process with `try ... finally`. Fixed #233 

Tested:
1. Launch a cluster with `sky launch -c test ./examples/job_queue/cluster.yaml`
2. Run a GPU program `sky exec -c test ./examples/job_queue/job_gpu.yaml`
3. Check the gpustat `sky exec -c test gpustat`
3. Cancel the job `sky cancel -c test 1`
4. Check the gpustat again `sky exec -c test gpustat -cpu -i 1`

Before the fix, the gpu will remain occupied after canceling. After the fix, the problem is solved.

title: Remove git SSH forwarding
body:
Adding git SSH forwarding has proven very difficult to test consistently and has been unreliable for different setups. Since we cannot support remotes that aren't GitHub easily nor can we support HTTPS auth forwarding, I am removing this automatic forwarding feature for now. 

The recommended approaches are either to set up ssh agent forwarding yourself (with [GitHub's tutorial](https://docs.github.com/en/developers/overview/using-ssh-agent-forwarding)) or to use their `gh auth` tool which works very well.

Closes #231. Closes #223.

### Tests
Ran smoke tests with no issues.

title: Add task.name checks
body:
Adds check if task.name is valid.

Valid task name is defined as either NoneType or str with ASCII characters which may contain lowercase and uppercase letters, digits, underscores, periods, and dashes. Must start and end with alphanumeric characters. No triple dashes or underscores.

Currently also allows `None` as a valid task name (even though it's not supported by Docker. However, I have allowed it for now since not allowing task.name=None is a bigger change that requires discussion. 

Fixes #222.

title: Only retry the original region when restarting cluster
body:
This PR partially solves the problem in #205 . We should not retry different regions when we are restarting a stopped cluster, since the attached volumes will be invisible in other regions.

The problem is hard to reproduce, so I manually tested the newly added function in `global_user_state.py` with an existing cluster_name, and the yield/raise execution order.
```python
>>> # The function correctly fetches the cluster status
>>> cluster_status = global_user_state.get_status_from_cluster_name('my-test')
>>> cluster_status == global_user_state.ClusterStatus.STOPPED
False
>>> cluster_status == global_user_state.ClusterStatus.UP
True
```
```python
>>> # The error raising will only be executed after the caller function requires 
>>> # the next item in the generator
>>> def gen():                                                                       
...     yield 1                                                                      
...     raise A                                                                      
...                                                                                  
>>> for i in gen():
...     print('1')
...     time.sleep(2)
...     print('2')
... 
1
2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "<stdin>", line 3, in gen
NameError: name 'A' is not defined
```

Future TODO: the `boto3` will keep retrying to start the cluster (max 12 times), and will take more than 40 mins before raising the error.

title: Fix git SSH agent forwarding issues
body:
Polishing SSH and git functionality.

### Tests
```
class c1:
  name = 'cluster1'
  ip = '127.0.0.1'
  auth_config = {'ssh_user': 'ubuntu', 'ssh_private_key': '~/.ssh/id_rsa'}

class c2:
  name = 'cluster2'
  ip = '127.0.0.2'
  auth_config = {'ssh_user': 'ubuntu', 'ssh_private_key': '~/.ssh/id_rsa'}

class c3:
  name = 'cluster3'
  ip = '127.0.0.3'
  auth_config = {'ssh_user': 'ubuntu', 'ssh_private_key': '~/.ssh/id_rsa'}

class c2_overwrite:
  name = 'cluster2'
  ip = 'overwrite'
  auth_config = {'ssh_user': 'ubuntu', 'ssh_private_key': '~/.ssh/id_rsa'}

# add some clusters
backend_utils.SSHConfigHelper.add_cluster(c1.name, c1.ip, c1.auth_config)
backend_utils.SSHConfigHelper.add_cluster(c2.name, c2.ip, c2.auth_config)
backend_utils.SSHConfigHelper.add_cluster(c3.name, c3.ip, c3.auth_config)
import pdb; pdb.set_trace()

# overwrite
backend_utils.SSHConfigHelper.add_cluster(c2_overwrite.name, c2_overwrite.ip, c2_overwrite.auth_config)

# delete middle config
backend_utils.SSHConfigHelper.remove_cluster(c2_overwrite.ip, c2_overwrite.auth_config)
```

title: Directly run the inline cmd on cluster without job queue
body:
This PR tends to make the `sky exec -c cluster "inline cmd"` faster without using the job queue. #197 

Proposal:
1. `sky exec -c cluster "inline cmd"`
    - The user means to run the comment immediately, so we directly run it through `ssh`, e.g. `sky exec -c cluster ls`.
    - Claim: The user should take responsibility that her inline command will not take other running tasks' resources when the resources option is not set, e.g. `srun --nodelist=blaze "inline cmd"` will not guarantee the task does not use GPU resources`.
    - This also solves the problem in #209. The user now can do `sky exec -c cluster -- htop`.
2. `sky exec -c cluster --gpus=V100:1 "inline cmd"` #200 
    - The user wants the resources to be guaranteed, so it will still use the job queue implementation.

Cons:
1. This will make the behavior of `sky exec -c cluster -- "cmd"` different from `sky exec -c cluster --gpus=V100:1 -- "cmd"`. The former one will not use job queue and will be interactive (Ctrl+C works), but the latter one will use the job queue and be non-interactive.

To decide (not sure if that would be a real use case):
1. The user may want to run an inline CPU command in a job queue.

FYI, cc @gmittal 

Tested:
- [x] `sky exec -c cluster -- htop`; `sky exec -c cluster htop` 
- [x] `sky exec -c cluster -- gpustat -cpu -i 1`
- [x] `sky exec -c cluster -- ls`; `sky exec -c cluster ls`

title: Fix the `-tt` option for ssh command while not in interactive mode
body:
https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/9e0703ddbd7dd5782bd7635fb35b79c993ec329d/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L1590
`ssh_head_command` will have a `-tt` option for the ssh command, which will force pseudo-terminal allocation for the connection. Switch to `-T` (disable pseudo-terminal allocation) for non-interactive mode solves the following problems:

1. It makes `sky exec -c jq -d examples/job_queue/job.yaml &` work. (Previously, we will have following error: `[1]  + 98936 suspended (tty output)  sky exec -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml > /dev/null`)
2. It resolve the problem we met before that the return value of ssh command was corrupted by keyboard input #196. 
  > when we get the output from the ssh subprocess, the keyboard input will appear in the stdout, like the following error (I type in `llhkukjbkubkiu`, when the program is fetching the job id). After adding the encoding and decoding, the problem is solved.
  ```bash
  ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'llhkukjbkubkiu1\r\n'
  ```

Tested:
- [x] `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh`
- [x] `sky cpunode`
- [x] `sky launch -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml`; `sky exec -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml` (type random characters while the program is running).
- [x] `sky queue -c min`
- [x] `sky logs -c min 1 -s` (type random characters while the program is running).

title: Fix skylet setup issue (skylet failed to be imported locally by a third-party package)
body:
Closes #192
Closes #194
Closes #198

In our current architecture, there are 3 cases we need global public access to sky package:

1. When spinning up a cluster, we call ray autoscaler. When using a custom cloud provider contained in sky (we need it to support key features not available in Ray, e.g., start/stop GCP and Azure, TPU non-vm instances), Ray will access a globally available python module.
2. Job queue and logging support in the cluster need access to some sky modules. These modules are also used by sky locally.
3. Ray autoscaler in the cluster need access to the cloud provider contained in sky.

There are 3 solutions:

1. Publish sky to pypi or make sky open accessible on github, so we have public access to the sky package. This is the solution of Ray autoscaler - you need to install Ray in the remote cluster from pypi or from a downloadable wheel.
2. Mount the entire sky package to the cluster. This package is not installable after mounting, so we need to further modify it (e.g. add a setup.py) and install it. Not sure this is achievable with our yaml file.
3. A separate package contained in sky called “skylet”. This is the current workaround. We can copy it to the cluster and install it directly. The drawback is that we need to ask the developers/contributors to install both sky and skylet; this is because for development, skylet and sky are installed with `editable` mode, with this mode we cannot directly install skylet when installing sky.

I think finally we would converge to solution 1. So I build the workaround based on solution 1.

This workaround builds a python wheel for sky locally and uploads it to the cluster. Then it installs sky in the cluster.

title: Make 'setup failed -> fix setup, rerun sky launch' work for 1-node.
body:
Bug nature:
- from a state where ray processes aren't up (due to setup failing)
- running 'sky launch' on this state does NOT recover ray processes due to our use of `--no-restart` flag
- the cluster therefore is unusable, must be `sky stop && sky start` manually

To reproduce, use `minimal.yaml`
- sky launch -c, with `exit 1` added to `setup` 
- fix setup (remove `exit 1`)
- sky launch -c again

Before this change:
```
I 01-13 16:58:07 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:713] Successfully provisioned or found existing VM. Setup completed.
I 01-13 16:58:07 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:715]
I 01-13 16:58:07 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:715] To log into the head VM:  ssh min2
I 01-13 16:58:07 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:715]
I 01-13 16:58:16 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1271] Reserved Job ID: 1
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399]
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] Cluster name: min2
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] To log into the head VM: ssh min2
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] To submit a job:         sky exec -c min2 yaml_file
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] To teardown the cluster: sky down min2
I 01-13 16:58:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1399] To stop the cluster:     sky stop min2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/execution.py", line 133, in _execute
    backend.execute(handle, task, stream_logs, detach_run)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1296, in execute
    stream_logs, detach_run)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1336, in _execute_task_one_node
    detach_run=detach_run)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1233, in _exec_code_on_head
    check=True)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1564, in _run_command_on_head_via_ssh
    check=check)
  File "/Users/zongheng/Dropbox/workspace/riselab/sky-computing/prototype/sky/backends/remote_libs/log_lib.py", line 87, in run_with_log
    raise RuntimeError('Command failed, please check the logs.')
RuntimeError: Command failed, please check the logs.
```

After this change:
- ray processes are restarted on the head, making this workflow succeed

----

**Known issue for the future: multinode recovery**
- this does not work for `multi_hostname.yaml` with injected `exit 1`
- the first `sky launch` would fail, putting the worker node forever in an `uninitialized` state, 
- ...which makes the second `sky launch` not be able to hit `_ensure_cluster_ray_started()`.

Workaround for multinode: advise users to manually `sky stop` and `sky start` after fixing the setup.

title: Tour of Sky notebook
body:
There's a lot of ground to cover and suggestions/contributions are welcome. My biggest concern right now is that the logs will just overwhelm the user (we should suppress the pip installs on cluster startup). A lot of this was inspired by @romilbhardwaj's quickstart docs. Goal was to go for something like [this](https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/notebooks/quickstart.html) and not something like [this](https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/pytrees.html).

If others are interested in contributing (and please do so!), feel free to use this as an integration branch (open PRs using this branch as the base instead of `master`).

Not all features are documented in this notebook because 1) some things are hard to demo in a notebook and 2) trivial examples for some things are a bit hard to construct and complicated to run without the notebook taking a while to get through. Since this is something a first-time user will use, we want to keep this short and reserve more advanced features/modes for a proper docs.

Potential features that should be discussed and could get their own sections:
- Storage @romilbhardwaj @michaelzhiluo 
- Job queue @Michaelvll

NOTE: to view the copy of the notebook without pulling the branch locally, [go here](https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/85077215d5adef6bd0ae84d45aa8909c8b1e9f1c/prototype/docs/tour-of-sky.ipynb)

title: Raise error if resources do not match when reusing interactive nodes
body:
We currently have no safeguards in place to prevent a user from changing specified resources when re-using a cluster. This PR catches when a user-specified resource mismatches launched resources in `[tpu|cpu|gpu]node`. We can keep `launch`'s resource check logic the same because the less-than-or-equal check is reasonable behavior there but not for interactive nodes.

### Tests
For interactive nodes:
```
sky gpunode -c t1 --gpus V100 --cloud aws # should succeed first time
sky gpunode -c t1                                             # should login
sky gpunode -c t1 --gpus K80                        # should error with this change
sky cpunode -c t1                                             # should error with this change
sky tpunode -c t1                                              # should error
sky gpunode -c t1 --gpus V100 --cloud aws # should login
```

title: Add agent forwarding for `sky [cpu|gpu|tpu]node` connections
body:
This fixes an issue raised by @concretevitamin.

Currently agent forwarding (for git credentials, etc.) only works when using `ssh` directly (e.g. `ssh my_cluster`). This can be confusing because `sky cpunode -c my_cluster` also provides an interactive session but agent forwarding is not present (and git operations won't work with your local SSH keys). This PR fixes that.

## Tests
- [x] Successfully cloned private repo with `sky cpunode -c my_cluster`

title: Add `sky start`.
body:
Problem: interactive node reuse
```bash
  sky gpunode -c cs285 --gpus=V100
  sky stop cs286

  # Does not restart:
  # sky.exceptions.ResourcesMismatchError: Requested resources do not match the existing cluster.
  #   Requested: 1x {None(None, {'K80': 1})}
  #   Existing: 1x {None(None, {'V100': 8})}
  # To fix: specify a new cluster name, or down the existing cluster first: sky down sky-gpunode-zongheng
  sky gpunode -c cs285

  # OK, but non-intuitive / may forget the original resources flags.
  sky gpunode -c cs285 --gpus=V100
```
Solution: `sky start`
```
  # Just need to use the cluster name (sky status).
  sky start cs285
```
This also handles restarting a stopped cluster that is originally launched by a task.yaml, but we don't want to use `sky run ... task.yaml` to restart it (e.g., we don't want to run the task).

test 'sky run' reuse
```bash
  sky run -c min examples/minimal.yaml
  sky ssh min
  touch hi
  sky stop min

  # Shows STOPPED.
  sky status

  # Writes a new config/user/min.yml where file_mounts/setup/workdir are empty.
  sky start min
  sky ssh min
  ls hi

  # Writes a new config/user/min.yml where file_mounts/setup/workdir are filled in.
  # file_mounts/setup/workdir are re-processed (idempotent).
  sky run -c min examples/minimal.yaml
```


test n-node clusters
```bash
sky run -c gang2 examples/multi_hostname.yaml
sky stop gang2
sky start gang2

# Works.
sky exec -c gang2 examples/multi_hostname.yaml
# Executing a different task works too.
sky exec -c gang2 examples/minimal.yaml
```

Tested smoke tests which pass except file mounts (tracked in #140).

title: Job Submission: Add support for job queue and management.
body:
This PR aims to provide better support for job queues with the support of `ray job`.

Main changes:
1. Replace the program submission logic with ray job.
2. New resource checking: task resources <= cluster.launched_resources.
3. New cli's for job queue.
4. Job queue information is stored on the database on cluster (for multitenancy) backed by sqlite3.
5. `sky logs` for tracking logs.

Added features:
1. `sky queue <cluster_name> [--all]` (--all: shows all the tasks including the finished ones; `sky queue cluster_name` will only show the finished task once).
```bash
> sky queue test --all
Sky Job Queue of Cluster: test
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| JOB |  SUBMITTED  |   STATUS  | LOG                                     |
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| 117 | 31 secs ago |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-57-40-379226 |
| 116 |  4 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-53-14-428524 |
| 115 |  5 mins ago |  STOPPED  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-52-29-825712 |
| 114 |  5 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-52-12-210650 |
| 113 | 20 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-38-02-089872 |
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
```
2. `sky cancel -c <cluster_name> [<job_id>|--all]`
3. `sky logs -c <cluster_name> <job_id>`: tailing the log of a job in real time.
4. To do detached execution: `sky exec -c <cluster_name> yaml_file --detach`.

TODOs:
- [x] Tested examples/minimal.yaml with multiple jobs (including accelerators).
- [x] Better job name for user's convenience.
- [x] Tested single nodes/multiple jobs with less demanding resources. (`examples/job_queue/cluster.yaml`; `examples/job_queue/job.yaml`: two jobs with V100: 0.5)
```bash
Sky Job Queue of Cluster: test
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| JOB |  SUBMITTED  |   STATUS  | LOG                                     |
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| 124 | 12 secs ago |  PENDING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-16-14-49-575592 |
| 123 | 20 secs ago |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-16-14-41-608605 |
| 122 | 29 secs ago |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-16-14-30-905822 |
| 121 |  2 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-16-12-38-642178 |
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
```
- [x] Pipe logs and add hints.
- [x] Test multiple nodes multi-node job. (`examples/job_queue/multinode.yaml`; `examples/job_queue/multinode_job.yaml`: two jobs with 2x K80: 0.5)
- [x] Multiple nodes with single-node job. (`examples/job_queue/multinode.yaml` with 2x K80; `examples/job_queue/job.yaml`: two jobs with 1x K80: 0.5: 4 jobs in parallel)
- [x] Multiple nodes with single-node job and multi-node job.
- [x] Distributed training with multiple nodes.
- [x] Test `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh`
- [x] Deprecate the ParTask and rewrite ParTask examples.


Future:
- (! Important) Fix job execution order. (ray seems not preserving the FIFO order of the job queue).
```bash
Sky Job Queue of Cluster test2
+-----+------+------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| JOB | USER | SUBMITTED  |   STATUS  | LOG                                     |
+-----+------+------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| 103 | zhwu | 2 mins ago |  PENDING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-36-36-737105 |
| 105 | zhwu | 1 min ago  |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-37-03-308653 |
| 104 | zhwu | 1 min ago  |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-36-50-699314 |
| 102 | zhwu | 2 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-36-23-662007 |
| 101 | zhwu | 2 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-36-06-512089 |
+-----+------+------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
```
- Fix executing job with num_nodes=2 on a cluster with 3 nodes. (This is blocked by the `post_setup_fn` design for distributed training).
- Fix log downloading logic. （When should we download the logs? Zongheng: maybe don't).
- Launching cluster for a task with `K80: 0.5` should round to `K80: 1`.

title: Sky Run `--setup/-s` and Bash File as Argument
body:
*This PR has been split into 2 parts. The first part, which is non controversial, just adds bash command for Sky Run and Exec. The second part, which is this PR, does `sky run --setup` and allows for bash file as argument/input.


Changes:
- [x] Sky Exec can take in a command or shell script instead of only a yaml file
- [x] Sky Run can also take in a command or shell script instead of only a yaml file
- [x] Sky Run can take in `--setup/-s` for setup script. 


Some examples below...

Sky Run
```
  #  Pass in commands

  >> sky run -c name -s 'echo Hello World' 'echo Bye World'

  # Pass in shell script

  >> sky run -c name -s setup.sh run.sh
```

Sky Exec
```
  #  Pass in commands for execution

  >> sky exec -c name 'echo Hello World'

  # Pass in shell script for execution

  >> sky exec -c name run.sh
```
